data_findings.finding: This is a 2D packing optimization problem: pack 1-200 Christmas trees into smallest square bounding boxes. Score = sum(s_n^2/n) for n=1 to 200. Lower is better. Target: 68.922808. Best public kernel: 71.78.
Tree shape: 15-vertex polygon with trunk (0.15x0.2), 3 tiers (base 0.7, mid 0.4, top 0.25), tip at y=0.8. Position defined by (x,y) at trunk top center and rotation angle (deg).
Key technique: Ensemble approach - collect best solutions per N from multiple sources (CSV files, kernels), then optimize further. This is the foundation of all top solutions.

Simulated Annealing (SA) with translations: C++ implementation with OpenMP parallelization. Key params: iterations (15000-50000), restarts (5-8), temperature schedule (1.0 to 0.000005). Includes local search and fractional translation refinement.
Fractional translation: Fine-grained optimization using tiny steps (0.001 to 0.00001) in 8 directions to nudge trees into tighter positions without overlap. Critical for final score improvement.

BackPacking strategy: Start from n=200 and iterate backward to n=1. When a configuration at n trees performs poorly, copy the best configuration found so far and drop extra trees. Propagates successful patterns.

Greedy construction: Place trees one by one, starting far from center and moving inward until collision, then backing up. Use weighted angle distribution (abs(sin(2*angle))) to favor diagonal placements for better corner filling.
Score impact varies by N: small N (1-20) contributes ~1.0 per tree, medium N (50-100) ~0.5, large N (150-200) ~0.3. Focus optimization on small N for maximum impact.

To beat public kernels: 1) Ensemble MORE sources, 2) Run SA LONGER, 3) Focus on high-impact N values, 4) Use multiple random restarts, 5) Implement novel construction approaches (not just optimize existing)
data_findings.source: web search on beating public kernels

data_findings.finding: Key data sources for ensemble: SmartManoj Santa Scoreboard (GitHub), bucket-of-chump dataset, santa25-public dataset, telegram-public-shared-solution dataset, all top kernel outputs

web_research.query: What are the best algorithms for 2D irregular polygon packing optimization problems?
web_research.finding: Two‑dimensional irregular polygon packing is a classic combinatorial optimisation problem that appears in sheet‑metal cutting, textile layout, furniture design and many other manufacturing processes.  Because the exact solution space grows exponentially with the number of pieces, the most successful approaches today are hybrid methods that combine fast constructive heuristics with powerful meta‑heuristic or local‑search refinements.  Constructive schemes such as the **bottom‑left placement** and **shelf‑based packing** provide quick feasible layouts and form the backbone of many modern solvers ([taylorfrancis.com](https://www.taylorfrancis.com/chapters/edit/10.1201/9781351236423-33/practical-algorithms-two-dimensional-packing-general-shapes-yannan-hu-hideki-hashimoto-shinji-imahori-mutsunori-yagiura)) ; they are often enhanced by a **2‑level algorithm with a collision‑free region** that resolves overlaps more efficiently ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/104990563/IRREGULAR_PLAC

web_research.query: How do Kaggle optimization competition winners achieve scores better than public kernels?
web_research.finding:
Based on the NVIDIA Grandmasters Playbook, DataCamp’s competition course, and practical tips from Kaggle veterans, winners of optimization competitions typically out‑perform the public kernels by following a disciplined, data‑driven workflow ([developer.nvidia.com](https://developer.nvidia.com/blog/the-kaggle-grandmasters-playbook-7-battle-tested-modeling-techniques-for-tabular-data); [campus.datacamp.com](https://campus.datacamp.com/courses/winning-a-kaggle-competition-in-python/modeling?ex=12); [learnbymarketing.com](https://learnbymarketing.com/848/what-tools-do-kaggle-winners-use); [yanirseroussi.com](https://yanirseroussi.com/2014/08/24/how-to-almost-win-kaggle-competitions)):

1. **Build a trustworthy validation scheme** – create custom folds that reflect the private test distribution (e.g., stratified, time‑based, or leakage‑aware splits) and keep the same folds for every experiment. This guards against over‑fitting to the public leaderboard ([learnbymarketing.com](https://learn
